Art. 4.213. 
Mission and powers of the executor 
The executor of the will affixes the seals, if there are minor heirs, protected persons who, pursuant to article 492/1 of the former Civil Code, have been declared incapable of accepting the succession, or heirs presumed to be absent.
In the presence of the heir presumptive, or the latter duly summoned, he makes an inventory of the estate's assets.
He arranges for the sale of the furniture if there is insufficient cash to pay the legacies.
He ensures that the will is executed. In the event of a dispute over its execution, he may intervene to support its validity.
At the end of the year following the death of the testator, he must render an account of his management.
The powers of the executor do not pass to his heirs.
If there are several executors who have accepted, only one can act in the absence of the others. They are jointly and severally liable for the account of the movable property entrusted to them, unless the testator has divided their duties and each of them has limited himself or herself to the duties assigned to him or her.
